awd_titl_txt: IRES: Cross-Cutting Interdisciplinary Research and Integration of Ecology and Biocultural Conservation in the World's Southernmost Forests
awd_abstract_narration:
Using a novel biocultural conservation approach integrating ecological sciences, arts and environmental philosophy, 18 students over three years will participate in theoretical and field-based research conducted in the pristine UNESCO's Cape Horn Biosphere Reserve, southern Chile. Mentored by Chilean and U.S. researchers, students will actively engage in crosscutting research in the context of global change integrating bryophyte and bird ecology, impact of invasive species, and the effects of water and air quality on aquatic invertebrates along altitudinal gradients. Additional objectives are to familiarize students with decision-making processes, engage them in regional educational programs focused on social and ecological well-being. They will gain hands-on experience at the interface of environmental science, policy and education, critical for understanding today's complex environmental issues.

This IRES presents a unique opportunity to engage U.S. STEM students in research, education, and conservation projects to prepare them to address complex ecological problems in a geographical area comparable to subpolar regions of North America. Students from groups typically underrepresented in STEM disciplines and in particular in conservation biology, will explore, alongside Chilean and other international researchers and students, the interfaces of environmental science, policy and education. They will share their learning and research experiences with local citizens through activities within the school and community to strengthen the understanding of the unique regional biodiversity to broaden their own perspectives of their scientific research and gain the viewpoint of the local community on their natural heritage.

por.por_cntn:
Twelve U.S. graduate (3 PhD and 6 MS) and seven undergraduate students from seven universities participated in a 4-6 moths research and cultural experience in the sub-Antarctic ecoregion in southernmost Chile.

Through diverse immersive experiences students learned about the rich cultural life of southern people both from European colonizers as well as from the native Yahgans. These included aspects of their history, way of living, languages, their relations with the land, the environment, and their world views.

Articulated and helped by their mentors, students learned how to conduct ecological and biocultural field research, beginning with the conception of the ideas, moving through the inquiry process, the development of the research, and the dissemination of the results. Novel results were produced in the form of several reports, 30 posters or presentations to professional conferences in seven countries on three continents, a dissertation, and six publications in scientific journals. These covered a great diversity of subjects including the study of impacts of exotic fishes on native fishes and aquatic invertebrate communities, pet dogs and cats impacts on wildlife, dispersal of tardigrades and mosses by birds, analyses of guided trails, taxonomic biases, and conservation policies in protected areas.

Several opportunities could be considered life changing experiences for the IRES students. For instance, through the international experience -the experience away from their comfort zone and "out of the box"- students learned about the importance of diverse of cultures, other world views, different ecosystems, and conflicts of people and how they use resources. They also appreciated that other people, having fewer resources, can still live a good life and in harmony with other life forms and beings. This helped them to appreciate and understand their own culture and that of others.

By conducting research through the inquiry approach, students learned on how to conduct research from A to Z, by starting from recognizing a problem, conducting a literature review, refining the research questions, preparing a short proposal, devising a plan, executing it, collecting the data, analyzing these, interpreting the results, writing a report, preparing a poster, and writing and submitting a manuscript. In each of these steps, students had to reflect, think critically and logically, make choices, and organize information. In some instances, students learned the hard way that processes can be improved through practical learning.

All these are very important learning experiences and growing processes that will be part of their toolboxes and will certainly help them in their future careers and lives. Most of these students gained a better appreciation for scientific research and will become future scientists.

Based in the formal independent assessment pre- and after the experience during each of the three years, there were significant positive impacts on the students. The IRES helped them become more conscious of the environment and cultural resources and to understand the connections between culture and environment: having students from various cultures and perspectives exposed the students to different viewpoints. Developing their own research projects helped students to become better scientists, realize the value of research in ecology, gain confidence in conducting research, to become independent thinkers and learn to be resourceful. They reported becoming more curious, slowing down in their ways of thinking to get deeper, become more inquisitive, and critical about their research and that the experience had a very positive impact on their professional development by improved their research skills more than they would in a traditional classroom setting.

The IRES allowed students to be part of the physical, cultural, social, and linguistic environment, which also opened their mind to different perspectives in research, appreciating their own lives and privileges they come with, traveling, and working together as a team irrespective of unfavorable outcomes. There was a positive and significant knowledge gain across several topics such as biological concepts, ecosystem, biological conservation, major paradigms, North-South experience, bilingual experience, intercultural dialog, biogeography, understanding local culture, and uniqueness of the place. Most of the students felt that the program prepared them to deal with international challenges by making them more open and adaptable to other cultures.
